column1: The usual dimensions of a cabin were sixteen by twenty feet. The timber for the building
column7: or persimmon. To make the foundations
column8: the men seized four of the thickest logs
column10: and notched and grooved and hammered them into as close a clinch as if they had grown so. The wood must grip by its own substance alone to hold up the pioneer's dwelling
column11: for there was not an iron nail to be had in the whole of the Back Country. Logs laid upon the foundation logs and notched into each other at the four corners formed the walls; and
column12: when these stood at seven feet
column13: the builders laid parallel timbers and puncheons to make both flooring and ceiling. The ridgepole of the roof was supported by two crotched trees and the roofing was made of logs and wooden slabs. The crevices of the walls were packed close with red clay and moss. Lastly
column14: spaces for a door and windows were cut out.
